argumentText:
We first prove the rearrangement inequality for the case $n=2$. Let
$x_1,x_2,y_1,y_2$ be real numbers such that $x_1\le x_2$ and $y_1\le
y_2$. Then $$(x_2-x_1)(y_2-y_1)\ge 0,$$ and therefore
$$x_1y_1+x_2y_2\ge x_1y_2+x_2y_1.$$ Equality holds iff $x_1=x_2$ or
$y_1=y_2$.\
\
For the general case, let $x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n$ and $y_1,y_2,\ldots,y_n$
be real numbers such that $x_1\le x_2\le\cdots\le
x_n$. Suppose that $(z_1,z_2,\ldots,z_n)$ is a permutation
(rearrangement) of $\{y_1,y_2,\ldots,y_n\}$ such that the sum
$$x_1z_1+x_2z_2+\cdots+x_nz_n$$ is maximized. If there exists a pair
$i<j$ with $z_i>z_j$, then $x_iz_j+x_jz_i\ge x_iz_i+x_jz_j$ (the $n=2$
case); equality holds iff $x_i=x_j$. Therefore,
$x_1z_1+x_2z_2+\cdots+x_nz_n$ is not maximal unless
$z_1\le z_2\le\cdots\le z_n$ or $x_i=x_j$ for all pairs $i<j$ such that
$z_i>z_j$. In the latter case, we can consecutively interchange these
pairs until $z_1\le z_2\le\cdots\le z_n$ (this is possible because the
number of pairs $i<j$ with $z_i>z_j$ decreases with each step). So
$x_1z_1+x_2z_2+\cdots+x_nz_n$ is maximized if
$$z_1\le z_2\le\cdots\le z_n.$$ To show that
$x_1z_1+x_2z_2+\cdots+x_nz_n$ is minimal for a permutation
$(z_1,z_2,\ldots,z_n)$ of $\{y_1,y_2,\ldots,y_n\}$ if
$z_1\ge z_2\ge\cdots\ge z_n$, observe that
$-(x_1z_1+x_2z_2+\cdots+x_nz_n)=x_1(-z_1)+x_2(-z_2)+\cdots+x_n(-z_n)$ is
maximized if $-z_1\le-z_2\le\cdots\le-z_n$. This implies that
$x_1z_1+x_2z_2+\cdots+x_nz_n$ is minimized if
$$z_1\ge z_2\ge\cdots\ge z_n.$$
